1087610.1007/10876.1572-8862Journal of Cluster ScienceIncluding Nanoclusters and NanoparticlesJ Clust Sci1040-72781572-8862Springer USNew Yorks10876-014-0797-y79710.1007/s10876-014-0797-yOriginal PaperHydrothermal Syntheses, Crystal Structure, and Photophysical Property of a Novel 2D Coordination Polymer with Holo-Directed Geometry of Lead(II)YanLi12aZengChao3LiChuan-Bi12grid.440799.7Key Laboratory of Preparation and Applications of Environmental Friendly Materials, Ministry of EducationJilin Normal University136000SipingPeople’s Republic of Chinagrid.440799.7College of ChemistryJilin Normal University136000SipingPeople’s Republic of ChinaBeijing Zhou Kou Dian Middle School102405BeijingPeople’s Republic of Chinayanli820618@163.com81020147201526410671076269201418820148102014© Springer Science+Business Media New York 20142014Abstract

One coordination polymer [Pb(ctpt)2(aic)·3H2O]n (1) [ctpt = 2-(4-Chloro-phenyl)-1H-1,3,7,8-tetraaza-cyclopenta[l]phenanthrene, aic = 5-Amino-isophthalic carboxylate] has been synthesized by hydrothermal reaction system and characterized by elemental analysis, thermogravimetric (TG) analysis, infrared spectrum and single-crystal X-ray diffraction. Complex 1 crystallizes with an N-donor chelating ligand and an aromatic dicarboxylate linker. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction reveals that 1 exhibits one-dimensional (1D) chain structure, and N–H···O hydrogen bonds lead the 1D chain structure to 2D layer framework. TG analysis shows clear courses of weight loss, which corresponds to the decomposition of different ligands. The photoluminescence properties of the coordination polymer have also been investigated.

The design and synthesis of coordination polymers with unusual structures and properties are attracting increasing attention, not only for their diverse structure types, but also for their potential applications as functional materials [1–6]. In this aspect, considerable progress has been made on the theoretical prediction and production of useful functional materials. Nowadays, the method of hydrothermal syntheses is widely used to obtain novel crystal structures, because it can solve the problems of ligands solubility and enhance the reactivity of reactants in the crystallization process to obtain perfect crystal. Nevertheless, it is still a great challenge to predict the exact structures and compositions of polymeric complexes assembled by coordination bonds and/or pi–pi interactions. The factors affecting packing of molecules and structure formation in crystallization are intricate and need to be further understood. In order to obtain novel functional complexes and investigate their structure–function relationships, we have synthesized one novel ligand: 2-(4-Chloro-phenyl)-1H-1,3,7,8-tetraaza-cyclopenta[l]phenanthrene (ctpt). ctpt is a derivative of 1,10-phenanthroline, which is a long-conjugated unsymmetrical rigid reagent which can not only act as a terminal ligand but also potentially provide supramolecular interactions such as aromatic stacking to construct intriguing structures. At this stage, combine N-heterocyclic ligands and anionic O-donor as mixed ligands with metal to design various architectures is considered an attractive design strategy [7, 8].

Until recently, research on coordination polymers has focused on incorporation of s-, d-, and even f-block metal ions as coordination centers, while less consideration has been given to the metals of the p block, despite their importance in electroluminescence, photovoltaic conversion, fluorescent sensors, and organic light-emitting diodes. Lead(II), as a heavy p-block metal ion, has a large radius and exhibits flexible coordination modes [9, 10]. Moreover, the stereo-chemical activity of the lone pair of electrons is an interesting issue, which is always discussed. In this paper, we use ctpt and aic (5-Amino-isophthalic acid) ligands to obtain one complex: [Pb(ctpt)2(aic) 3H2O]n (1).

ExperimentalMaterials

The ligand ctpt was prepared by the method according to the description in the literature procedures [11, 12]. All the other chemicals from commercial sources were of AR grade and used without further purification.

Instruments and Measurements

The FT-IR spectrum was recorded on an Alpha Centauri FT-IR spectrophotometer. TG analysis was performed with a Diamond DSC thermal analyzer at the rate of 10 °C/min rise of temperature in nitrogen atmosphere. Crystal structures were determined on a Bruker SMART APEX II CCD X-ray diffractometer. Elemental analyses of C, H and N were performed on a PE-2400 elemental analyzer. Fluorescence spectra were recorded on a FLSP 920 Edinburgh fluorescence spectrometer.

Synthesis of ctpt

A mixture of 4-Chloro-benzaldehyde, 1,10-phenanthroline- 5,6-dione (0.525 g, 2.5 mmol), ammonium acetate (3.88 g, 50 mmol) and glacial acetic acid was refluxed for 6 h, and then cooled to room temperature. Yellow precipitate was obtained when addition of concentrated aqueous ammonia to neutralize, which was collected and washed with water. The crude product dissolved in ethanol was purified by filtration on silica gel. The principal yellow band was obtained. Then evaporation of the solution gave yellow products. Yield 0.63 g, 70 %. m.p. 316–322 °C. 1H NMR (CDCl3, ppm): 3.57 (s, 1H, NH), 6.73–7.65 (m, 4H, Ar–H), 7.92–9.11 (m, 6H, aromatic protons in the moiety of phenanthroline, Ar–H). MS (ESI): m/z = 330.1 [M+1]+, 352.1 [M+Na]+.

Synthesis of [Pb(ctpt)<sub>2</sub>(aic) 3H<sub>2</sub>O]<sub>n</sub>(1)

A mixture of Pb(AC)2 3H2O (0.11 g, 0.3 mmol), ctpt, carboxylate and H2O (18 mL) was stirred at room temperature and adjusted the pH value to about 7.0 with NaOH (20 %). We put the cloudy solution into a 30-mL Teflon-lined stainless vessel at 170 °C for 3 days and afterwards cooled to room temperature at a rate of 5 °C/h. The yellow crystals of complex 1 were obtained in 81 % yield based on Pb (0.33 g). C46H31Cl2N9O7Pb: calcd. C 50.23, H 2.84, N 11.46 %; found: C 50.19, H 2.86, N 11.41 %. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3418(s), 3392(s), 1612(vs), 1587(vs), 1398(vs), 1289(s), 1108(s), 731(s), 510(m).

X-ray Crystallography

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction data were collected at room temperature with a Bruker SMART APEX II CCD diffractometer equipped with a graphite-monochromatized MoKα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at 293(2) K in the range of 1.72° ≤ θ ≤ 26.08° for 1. Absorption corrections were applied using multi-scan technique and all the structures were solved by direct methods with SHELXS-97 [13] and refined with SHELXL-97 [14] by full-matrix least-squares techniques on F2. Non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic temperature parameters. All H atoms were positioned geometrically (C–H = 0.093 nm for CH or 0.096 nm for CH3) and refined as a riding mode, with Uiso(H) = 1.2Ueq(C). Further crystallographic data and experimental details for structural analyses of title complex are summarized in Table 1.

Results and DiscussionDescription of Crystal Structures

The molecular structure of complex 1 is shown in Fig. 1. The 1D zigzag-chain structure is suggested in Fig. 2, and the simplified 1D chain structure is suggested in Fig. 3. The 2D structure linked by hydrogen bonds is shown in Fig. 4. Selected important bond lengths and bond angles are given in Table 2.

As shown in Fig. 1, the asymmetric unit contains one Pb atom, two ctpt ligands, one aic ligand and three lattice water molecules. In 1, the Pb atom is hexa-coordinated with three carboxylate oxygen atoms from two distinct aic ligands, and three nitrogen atoms donors from two ctpt ligands, forming distorted [PbN3O3] pentagonal-bipyramidal geometry. The bond distances of Pb–O in 1 are from 2.507(3) to 2.712(4) Å, and those of Pb–N bond distances fall in the 2.584(3)–2.736(4) Å range, which are similar with the values reported [8, 15–17]. As shown in Fig. 2, one aic ligand coordinates to two Pb ions through three carboxylic oxygen atoms in mono-bridging and bidentate chelating fashion, which give rise to a 1D zigzag-chain structure and the distance of Pb···Pb is 10.364 Å. N-heterocyclic ligands mtp are attached to both sides of this chain regularly, In order to get better insight into the framework, we omit the ctpt ligands to obtain the simplified 1D chain network (Fig. 3).

There are two types of H-bonds interactions in complex 1: N–H···O interactions and C–H···O interactions. The most interesting aspect of the structure in 1 concerns the intermolecular N–H···O [H(8B)···O(1) = 1.88 Å, N(8)···O(1) = 2.73 Å and N(8)–H(8B)···O(1) = 157°] interactions, which help in the construction of the 2D layer structure (Fig. 4). It is an interesting issue for the lone pair of electrons of Pb(II), which is always discussed. The geometries of Pb(II) complexes can be classified as (1) holo-directed, in which the bonds to ligand atoms are distributed throughout the surface of an encompassing globe, and (2) hemi-directed, in which the bonds to ligand atoms are directed throughout only part of the globe [18]. The coordination environment of Pb(II) in complex 1 is a good example of the holo-directed coordination, that is, the bonds to the ligand atoms are distributed throughout the surface of the encompassing Pb(II) sphere.

IR Spectra

The FT-IR spectra absorption peaks at 3418, 3392 cm−1 for 1 correspond to the stretching vibration of OH in the water. The strong characteristic absorption peaks at 1,612 and 1,587 are attributed to the antisymmetric stretching vibration of the coordinated carboxyl groups, and the peak at 1,398 cm−1 corresponds to the symmetric stretching of carboxyl. The separations are 214 and 189 cm−1, which indicates that the carboxyls groups adopt monodentate and bidentate coordination modes. The characteristic absorption of ctpt ligands appear at 1289, 1108 cm−1, and the absorption peaks at 731 and 510 cm−1 are ascribed to v (Pb–N). The IR results are good agreement with their solid structural features from the results of their crystal structures.

Thermal Analysis

TG analysis was used to investigate the thermal stability of 1 (Fig. 5). As expected, complex 1 exhibits three weight loss processes. First weight loss of 5.00 % from 80 to 145 °C reveals the loss of lattice water molecules (calcd. 4.91 %), and the second weight loss of 18.50 % from 145 to 361 °C corresponds to the loss of aic ligands (calcd. 18.91 %). The last weight loss reveals the loss of ctpt ligands (calcd. 60.02 %, found. 60.00 %). The final formation may be the metal oxide.

XRPD Patterns of Complex 1

Complex 1 was characterized by X-ray powder dif-fraction (XRPD) at room temperature. The simulated and experimental XRPD patterns of 1 are shown in Fig. 6. The patterns calculated from the single-crystal X-ray data of 1 are in good agreement with the observed in almost identical peak position except for some different peak intensities, which indicates the phase purity of the products.

Photoluminescent Properties

In this study, we research the luminescence of 1 (Fig. 7). Complex 1 shows one strong emission band at 534 nm (excitation at 320 nm). To further analyze the nature of these emission bands, the emission properties of aic and ctpt ligands are also investigated under the same experimental conditions. The free ligand ctpt exhibits one emission band at 495 nm, and aic exhibits one emission band at 438 nm (excitation at 320 nm). The results suggest that complex 1 is red-shifted by 39 nm relative to that of free ligand, and red-shifted by 96 nm relative to that of aic ligand. The emission bands for the free ligands are probably attributable to the π*-n transitions. The emission of complex 1 can be attributed to a metal-centered transition involving the s and p metal orbitals, as proposed by Vogler et al. [19, 20]. However, the effect of the microenvironment between ligands and complex on the luminescence properties still needs further investigations. Complex 1 may be good candidate for potential photoluminescence materials, because it is highly thermally stable and insoluble in water and common organic solvents.

Conclusions

In summary, we synthesized one new metal–organic complex by using plane multifunctional ligands ctpt. This material will give new impetus to the construction of novel functional material with potentially useful physical properties. The complex has been hydrothermally synthesized and structurally characterized by elemental analysis, IR spectrum, TG, and single-crystal X-ray diffraction. The title complex is highly thermal stabile and insoluble in water and common organic solvents, which is worthy of further study as candidate of potential photoluminescence material.

Supplementary Material

CCDC 1000539 contains the supplementary crystallographic data for 1, respectively. These data can be obtained free of charge from the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre via www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/ data request. cif.

The title complex is highly thermal stabile and insoluble in water and common organic solvents, which is worthy of further study as candidate of potential photoluminescence material.Supplementary MaterialCCDC 1000539 contains the supplementary crystallographic data for 1, respectively. elements.content: One coordination polymer [Pb(ctpt)2(aic)·3H2O]n (1) [ctpt = 2-(4-Chloro-phenyl)-1H-1,3,7,8-tetraaza-cyclopenta[l]phenanthrene, aic = 5-Amino-isophthalic carboxylate] has been synthesized by hydrothermal reaction system and characterized by elemental analysis, thermogravimetric (TG) analysis, infrared spectrum and single-crystal X-ray diffraction. Complex 1 crystallizes with an N-donor chelating ligand and an aromatic dicarboxylate linker. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction reveals that 1 exhibits one-dimensional (1D) chain structure, and N–H···O hydrogen bonds lead the 1D chain structure to 2D layer framework. TG analysis shows clear courses of weight loss, which corresponds to the decomposition of different ligands. The photoluminescence properties of the coordination polymer have also been investigated.
elements.clean_text:
Abstract

One coordination polymer [Pb(ctpt)2(aic)⋅3H2O]n (1) [ctpt = 2-(4-Chloro-phenyl)-1H-1,3,7,8-tetraaza-cyclopenta[l]phenanthrene, aic = 5-Amino-isophthalic carboxylate] has been synthesized by hydrothermal reaction system and characterized by elemental analysis, thermogravimetric (TG) analysis, infrared spectrum and single-crystal X-ray diffraction. Complex 1 crystallizes with an N-donor chelating ligand and an aromatic dicarboxylate linker. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction reveals that 1 exhibits one-dimensional (1D) chain structure, and N-H⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen bonds lead the 1D chain structure to 2D layer framework. TG analysis shows clear courses of weight loss, which corresponds to the decomposition of different ligands. The photoluminescence properties of the coordination polymer have also been investigated.

elements.content: The design and synthesis of coordination polymers with unusual structures and properties are attracting increasing attention, not only for their diverse structure types, but also for their potential applications as functional materials [1–6]. In this aspect, considerable progress has been made on the theoretical prediction and production of useful functional materials. Nowadays, the method of hydrothermal syntheses is widely used to obtain novel crystal structures, because it can solve the problems of ligands solubility and enhance the reactivity of reactants in the crystallization process to obtain perfect crystal. Nevertheless, it is still a great challenge to predict the exact structures and compositions of polymeric complexes assembled by coordination bonds and/or pi–pi interactions. The factors affecting packing of molecules and structure formation in crystallization are intricate and need to be further understood. In order to obtain novel functional complexes and investigate their structure–function relationships, we have synthesized one novel ligand: 2-(4-Chloro-phenyl)-1H-1,3,7,8-tetraaza-cyclopenta[l]phenanthrene (ctpt). ctpt is a derivative of 1,10-phenanthroline, which is a long-conjugated unsymmetrical rigid reagent which can not only act as a terminal ligand but also potentially provide supramolecular interactions such as aromatic stacking to construct intriguing structures. At this stage, combine N-heterocyclic ligands and anionic O-donor as mixed ligands with metal to design various architectures is considered an attractive design strategy [7, 8].
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The design and synthesis of coordination polymers with unusual structures and properties are attracting increasing attention, not only for their diverse structure types, but also for their potential applications as functional materials [1-6]. In this aspect, considerable progress has been made on the theoretical prediction and production of useful functional materials. Nowadays, the method of hydrothermal syntheses is widely used to obtain novel crystal structures, because it can solve the problems of ligands solubility and enhance the reactivity of reactants in the crystallization process to obtain perfect crystal. Nevertheless, it is still a great challenge to predict the exact structures and compositions of polymeric complexes assembled by coordination bonds and/or pi-pi interactions. The factors affecting packing of molecules and structure formation in crystallization are intricate and need to be further understood. In order to obtain novel functional complexes and investigate their structure-function relationships, we have synthesized one novel ligand: 2-(4-Chloro-phenyl)-1H-1,3,7,8-tetraaza-cyclopenta[l]phenanthrene (ctpt). ctpt is a derivative of 1,10-phenanthroline, which is a long-conjugated unsymmetrical rigid reagent which can not only act as a terminal ligand but also potentially provide supramolecular interactions such as aromatic stacking to construct intriguing structures. At this stage, combine N-heterocyclic ligands and anionic O-donor as mixed ligands with metal to design various architectures is considered an attractive design strategy [7, 8].

elements.content: Until recently, research on coordination polymers has focused on incorporation of s-, d-, and even f-block metal ions as coordination centers, while less consideration has been given to the metals of the p block, despite their importance in electroluminescence, photovoltaic conversion, fluorescent sensors, and organic light-emitting diodes. Lead(II), as a heavy p-block metal ion, has a large radius and exhibits flexible coordination modes [9, 10]. Moreover, the stereo-chemical activity of the lone pair of electrons is an interesting issue, which is always discussed. In this paper, we use ctpt and aic (5-Amino-isophthalic acid) ligands to obtain one complex: [Pb(ctpt)2(aic) 3H2O]n (1).

Lead(II), as a heavy p-block metal ion, has a large radius and exhibits flexible coordination modes [9, 10]. Moreover, the stereo-chemical activity of the lone pair of electrons is an interesting issue, which is always discussed. In this paper, we use ctpt and aic (5-Amino-isophthalic acid) ligands to obtain one complex: [Pb(ctpt)2(aic) 3H2O]n (1).

Experimental

Materials

The ligand ctpt was prepared by the method according to the description in the literature procedures [11, 12]. All the other chemicals from commercial sources were of AR grade and used without further purification.

elements.content: The FT-IR spectrum was recorded on an Alpha Centauri FT-IR spectrophotometer. TG analysis was performed with a Diamond DSC thermal analyzer at the rate of 10 °C/min rise of temperature in nitrogen atmosphere. Crystal structures were determined on a Bruker SMART APEX II CCD X-ray diffractometer. Elemental analyses of C, H and N were performed on a PE-2400 elemental analyzer. Fluorescence spectra were recorded on a FLSP 920 Edinburgh fluorescence spectrometer.

Instruments and Measurements

elements.content: A mixture of 4-Chloro-benzaldehyde, 1,10-phenanthroline- 5,6-dione (0.525 g, 2.5 mmol), ammonium acetate (3.88 g, 50 mmol) and glacial acetic acid was refluxed for 6 h, and then cooled to room temperature. Yellow precipitate was obtained when addition of concentrated aqueous ammonia to neutralize, which was collected and washed with water. The crude product dissolved in ethanol was purified by filtration on silica gel. The principal yellow band was obtained. Then evaporation of the solution gave yellow products. Yield 0.63 g, 70 %. m.p. 316–322 °C. 1H NMR (CDCl3, ppm): 3.57 (s, 1H, NH), 6.73–7.65 (m, 4H, Ar–H), 7.92–9.11 (m, 6H, aromatic protons in the moiety of phenanthroline, Ar–H). MS (ESI): m/z = 330.1 [M+1]+, 352.1 [M+Na]+.

Synthesis of ctpt

A mixture of 4-Chloro-benzaldehyde, 1,10-phenanthroline- 5,6-dione (0.525 g, 2.5 mmol), ammonium acetate (3.88 g, 50 mmol) and glacial acetic acid was refluxed for 6 h, and then cooled to room temperature. Yellow precipitate was obtained when addition of concentrated aqueous ammonia to neutralize, which was collected and washed with water. The crude product dissolved in ethanol was purified by filtration on silica gel. The principal yellow band was obtained. Then evaporation of the solution gave yellow products. Yield 0.63 g, 70 %. m.p. 316-322 °C. 1H NMR (CDCl3, ppm): 3.57 (s, 1H, NH), 6.73-7.65 (m, 4H, Ar-H), 7.92-9.11 (m, 6H, aromatic protons in the moiety of phenanthroline, Ar-H). MS (ESI): m/z = 330.1 [M+1]+, 352.1 [M+Na]+.

elements.content: A mixture of Pb(AC)2 3H2O (0.11 g, 0.3 mmol), ctpt, carboxylate and H2O (18 mL) was stirred at room temperature and adjusted the pH value to about 7.0 with NaOH (20 %). We put the cloudy solution into a 30-mL Teflon-lined stainless vessel at 170 °C for 3 days and afterwards cooled to room temperature at a rate of 5 °C/h. The yellow crystals of complex 1 were obtained in 81 % yield based on Pb (0.33 g). C46H31Cl2N9O7Pb: calcd. C 50.23, H 2.84, N 11.46 %; found: C 50.19, H 2.86, N 11.41 %. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3418(s), 3392(s), 1612(vs), 1587(vs), 1398(vs), 1289(s), 1108(s), 731(s), 510(m).
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of [Pb(ctpt)2(aic) 3H2O]n(1)

A mixture of Pb(AC)2 3H2O (0.11 g, 0.3 mmol), ctpt, carboxylate and H2O (18 mL) was stirred at room temperature and adjusted the pH value to about 7.0 with NaOH (20 %). We put the cloudy solution into a 30-mL Teflon-lined stainless vessel at 170 °C for 3 days and afterwards cooled to room temperature at a rate of 5 °C/h. The yellow crystals of complex 1 were obtained in 81 % yield based on Pb (0.33 g). C46H31Cl2N9O7Pb: calcd. C 50.23, H 2.84, N 11.46 %; found: C 50.19, H 2.86, N 11.41 %. IR (KBr, cm-1): 3418(s), 3392(s), 1612(vs), 1587(vs), 1398(vs), 1289(s), 1108(s), 731(s), 510(m).

elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray diffraction data were collected at room temperature with a Bruker SMART APEX II CCD diffractometer equipped with a graphite-monochromatized MoKα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at 293(2) K in the range of 1.72° ≤ θ ≤ 26.08° for 1. Absorption corrections were applied using multi-scan technique and all the structures were solved by direct methods with SHELXS-97 [13] and refined with SHELXL-97 [14] by full-matrix least-squares techniques on F2. Non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic temperature parameters. All H atoms were positioned geometrically (C–H = 0.093 nm for CH or 0.096 nm for CH3) and refined as a riding mode, with Uiso(H) = 1.2Ueq(C). Further crystallographic data and experimental details for structural analyses of title complex are summarized in Table 1.
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Crystallography

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction data were collected at room temperature with a Bruker SMART APEX II CCD diffractometer equipped with a graphite-monochromatized MoKα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at 293(2) K in the range of 1.72° ≤ θ ≤ 26.08° for 1. Absorption corrections were applied using multi-scan technique and all the structures were solved by direct methods with SHELXS-97 [13] and refined with SHELXL-97 [14] by full-matrix least-squares techniques on F2. Non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic temperature parameters. All H atoms were positioned geometrically (C-H = 0.093 nm for CH or 0.096 nm for CH3) and refined as a riding mode, with Uiso(H) = 1.2Ueq(C). Further crystallographic data and experimental details for structural analyses of title complex are summarized in Table 1.

As shown in Fig. 1, the asymmetric unit contains one Pb atom, two ctpt ligands, one aic ligand and three lattice water molecules. In 1, the Pb atom is hexa-coordinated with three carboxylate oxygen atoms from two distinct aic ligands, and three nitrogen atoms donors from two ctpt ligands, forming distorted [PbN3O3] pentagonal-bipyramidal geometry. The bond distances of Pb–O in 1 are from 2.507(3) to 2.712(4) Å, and those of Pb–N bond distances fall in the 2.584(3)–2.736(4) Å range, which are similar with the values reported [8, 15–17]. As shown in Fig. 2, one aic ligand coordinates to two Pb ions through three carboxylic oxygen atoms in mono-bridging and bidentate chelating fashion, which give rise to a 1D zigzag-chain structure and the distance of Pb···Pb is 10.364 Å. N-heterocyclic ligands mtp are attached to both sides of this chain regularly, In order to get better insight into the framework, we omit the ctpt ligands to obtain the simplified 1D chain network (Fig. 3).

In 1, the Pb atom is hexa-coordinated with three carboxylate oxygen atoms from two distinct aic ligands, and three nitrogen atoms donors from two ctpt ligands, forming distorted [PbN3O3] pentagonal-bipyramidal geometry. The bond distances of Pb-O in 1 are from 2.507(3) to 2.712(4) Å, and those of Pb-N bond distances fall in the 2.584(3)-2.736(4) Å range, which are similar with the values reported [8, 15-17]. As shown in Fig. 2, one aic ligand coordinates to two Pb ions through three carboxylic oxygen atoms in mono-bridging and bidentate chelating fashion, which give rise to a 1D zigzag-chain structure and the distance of Pb⋅⋅⋅Pb is 10.364 Å. N-heterocyclic ligands mtp are attached to both sides of this chain regularly, In order to get better insight into the framework, we omit the ctpt ligands to obtain the simplified 1D chain network (Fig. 3).

elements.content: There are two types of H-bonds interactions in complex 1: N–H···O interactions and C–H···O interactions. The most interesting aspect of the structure in 1 concerns the intermolecular N–H···O [H(8B)···O(1) = 1.88 Å, N(8)···O(1) = 2.73 Å and N(8)–H(8B)···O(1) = 157°] interactions, which help in the construction of the 2D layer structure (Fig. 4). It is an interesting issue for the lone pair of electrons of Pb(II), which is always discussed. The geometries of Pb(II) complexes can be classified as (1) holo-directed, in which the bonds to ligand atoms are distributed throughout the surface of an encompassing globe, and (2) hemi-directed, in which the bonds to ligand atoms are directed throughout only part of the globe [18]. The coordination environment of Pb(II) in complex 1 is a good example of the holo-directed coordination, that is, the bonds to the ligand atoms are distributed throughout the surface of the encompassing Pb(II) sphere.

elements.content: The FT-IR spectra absorption peaks at 3418, 3392 cm−1 for 1 correspond to the stretching vibration of OH in the water. The strong characteristic absorption peaks at 1,612 and 1,587 are attributed to the antisymmetric stretching vibration of the coordinated carboxyl groups, and the peak at 1,398 cm−1 corresponds to the symmetric stretching of carboxyl. The separations are 214 and 189 cm−1, which indicates that the carboxyls groups adopt monodentate and bidentate coordination modes. The characteristic absorption of ctpt ligands appear at 1289, 1108 cm−1, and the absorption peaks at 731 and 510 cm−1 are ascribed to v (Pb–N). The IR results are good agreement with their solid structural features from the results of their crystal structures.
elements.clean_text:
IR Spectra

The FT-IR spectra absorption peaks at 3418, 3392 cm-1 for 1 correspond to the stretching vibration of OH in the water. The strong characteristic absorption peaks at 1,612 and 1,587 are attributed to the antisymmetric stretching vibration of the coordinated carboxyl groups, and the peak at 1,398 cm-1 corresponds to the symmetric stretching of carboxyl. The separations are 214 and 189 cm-1, which indicates that the carboxyls groups adopt monodentate and bidentate coordination modes. The characteristic absorption of ctpt ligands appear at 1289, 1108 cm-1, and the absorption peaks at 731 and 510 cm-1 are ascribed to v (Pb-N). The IR results are good agreement with their solid structural features from the results of their crystal structures.

elements.content: TG analysis was used to investigate the thermal stability of 1 (Fig. 5). As expected, complex 1 exhibits three weight loss processes. First weight loss of 5.00 % from 80 to 145 °C reveals the loss of lattice water molecules (calcd. 4.91 %), and the second weight loss of 18.50 % from 145 to 361 °C corresponds to the loss of aic ligands (calcd. 18.91 %). The last weight loss reveals the loss of ctpt ligands (calcd. 60.02 %, found. 60.00 %). The final formation may be the metal oxide.

Thermal Analysis

TG analysis was used to investigate the thermal stability of 1 (Fig. 5). As expected, complex 1 exhibits three weight loss processes. First weight loss of 5.00 % from 80 to 145 °C reveals the loss of lattice water molecules (calcd. 4.91 %), and the second weight loss of 18.50 % from 145 to 361 °C corresponds to the loss of aic ligands (calcd. 18.91 %). The last weight loss reveals the loss of ctpt ligands (calcd. 60.02 %, found. 60.00 %). The final formation may be the metal oxide.

elements.content: In this study, we research the luminescence of 1 (Fig. 7). Complex 1 shows one strong emission band at 534 nm (excitation at 320 nm). To further analyze the nature of these emission bands, the emission properties of aic and ctpt ligands are also investigated under the same experimental conditions. The free ligand ctpt exhibits one emission band at 495 nm, and aic exhibits one emission band at 438 nm (excitation at 320 nm). The results suggest that complex 1 is red-shifted by 39 nm relative to that of free ligand, and red-shifted by 96 nm relative to that of aic ligand. The emission bands for the free ligands are probably attributable to the π*-n transitions. The emission of complex 1 can be attributed to a metal-centered transition involving the s and p metal orbitals, as proposed by Vogler et al. [19, 20]. However, the effect of the microenvironment between ligands and complex on the luminescence properties still needs further investigations. Complex 1 may be good candidate for potential photoluminescence materials, because it is highly thermally stable and insoluble in water and common organic solvents.
elements.clean_text:
Photoluminescent Properties

In this study, we research the luminescence of 1 (Fig. 7). Complex 1 shows one strong emission band at 534 nm (excitation at 320 nm). To further analyze the nature of these emission bands, the emission properties of aic and ctpt ligands are also investigated under the same experimental conditions. The free ligand ctpt exhibits one emission band at 495 nm, and aic exhibits one emission band at 438 nm (excitation at 320 nm). The results suggest that complex 1 is red-shifted by 39 nm relative to that of free ligand, and red-shifted by 96 nm relative to that of aic ligand. The emission bands for the free ligands are probably attributable to the π*-n transitions. The emission of complex 1 can be attributed to a metal-centered transition involving the s and p metal orbitals, as proposed by Vogler et al. [19, 20]. However, the effect of the microenvironment between ligands and complex on the luminescence properties still needs further investigations. Complex 1 may be good candidate for potential photoluminescence materials, because it is highly thermally stable and insoluble in water and common organic solvents.

elements.content: In summary, we synthesized one new metal–organic complex by using plane multifunctional ligands ctpt. This material will give new impetus to the construction of novel functional material with potentially useful physical properties. The complex has been hydrothermally synthesized and structurally characterized by elemental analysis, IR spectrum, TG, and single-crystal X-ray diffraction. Conclusions

In summary, we synthesized one new metal-organic complex by using plane multifunctional ligands ctpt. This material will give new impetus to the construction of novel functional material with potentially useful physical properties. The complex has been hydrothermally synthesized and structurally characterized by elemental analysis, IR spectrum, TG, and single-crystal X-ray diffraction. The title complex is highly thermal stabile and insoluble in water and common organic solvents, which is worthy of further study as candidate of potential photoluminescence material.

A mixture of 4-Chloro-benzaldehyde, 1,10-phenanthroline- 5,6-dione (0.525 g, 2.5 mmol), ammonium acetate (3.88 g, 50 mmol) and glacial acetic acid was refluxed for 6 h, and then cooled to room temperature. Yellow precipitate was obtained when addition of concentrated aqueous ammonia to neutralize, which was collected and washed with water. The crude product dissolved in ethanol was purified by filtration on silica gel. The principal yellow band was obtained. Then evaporation of the solution gave yellow products. Yield 0.63 g, 70 %. m.p. 316–322 °C. 1H NMR (CDCl3, ppm): 3.57 (s, 1H, NH), 6.73–7.65 (m, 4H, Ar–H), 7.92–9.11 (m, 6H, aromatic protons in the moiety of phenanthroline, Ar–H). MS (ESI): m/z = 330.1 [M+1]+, 352.1 [M+Na]+.

Synthesis of [Pb(ctpt)<sub>2</sub>(aic) 3H<sub>2</sub>O]<sub>n</sub>(1)

A mixture of Pb(AC)2 3H2O (0.11 g, 0.3 mmol), ctpt, carboxylate and H2O (18 mL) was stirred at room temperature and adjusted the pH value to about 7.0 with NaOH (20 %). We put the cloudy solution into a 30-mL Teflon-lined stainless vessel at 170 °C for 3 days and afterwards cooled to room temperature at a rate of 5 °C/h. The yellow crystals of complex 1 were obtained in 81 % yield based on Pb (0.33 g). C46H31Cl2N9O7Pb: calcd. C 50.23, H 2.84, N 11.46 %; found: C 50.19, H 2.86, N 11.41 %. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3418(s), 3392(s), 1612(vs), 1587(vs), 1398(vs), 1289(s), 1108(s), 731(s), 510(m).

cln_elements.content:
TG analysis was used to investigate the thermal stability of 1 (Fig. 5). As expected, complex 1 exhibits three weight loss processes. First weight loss of 5.00 % from 80 to 145 °C reveals the loss of lattice water molecules (calcd. 4.91 %), and the second weight loss of 18.50 % from 145 to 361 °C corresponds to the loss of aic ligands (calcd. 18.91 %). The last weight loss reveals the loss of ctpt ligands (calcd. 60.02 %, found. 60.00 %). The final formation may be the metal oxide.

Photoluminescent Properties

In this study, we research the luminescence of 1 (Fig. 7). Complex 1 shows one strong emission band at 534 nm (excitation at 320 nm). To further analyze the nature of these emission bands, the emission properties of aic and ctpt ligands are also investigated under the same experimental conditions. The free ligand ctpt exhibits one emission band at 495 nm, and aic exhibits one emission band at 438 nm (excitation at 320 nm). The results suggest that complex 1 is red-shifted by 39 nm relative to that of free ligand, and red-shifted by 96 nm relative to that of aic ligand. The emission bands for the free ligands are probably attributable to the π*-n transitions. The emission of complex 1 can be attributed to a metal-centered transition involving the s and p metal orbitals, as proposed by Vogler et al. [19, 20]. However, the effect of the microenvironment between ligands and complex on the luminescence properties still needs further investigations. Complex 1 may be good candidate for potential photoluminescence materials, because it is highly thermally stable and insoluble in water and common organic solvents.
